content:
Step 1 - Extractively Summarize the curr_chunk, try to preserve key details, and condense the text by removing irrelevant words:

Step 2 - To assist you with the task, here is the context of the paragraphs before it, to give you an idea on the information flow, and it is contained here in this prev_chunk:

Step 3: Make sure that the prev_chunk and curr_chunk is not redundant with words, and ideas. Both should at least be distinct as they are separate text chunks

Step 4: Output the summarized chunk The Secretary will develop alternative dispute resolution methods for resolving claims under section 161, including arbitration, mediation, and early offers of settlement. These methods must be affordable, timely, and ensure consistent and fair resolution of claims. The Secretary will develop alternative dispute resolution methods for resolving claims under section 161, including arbitration, mediation, and early offers of settlement, ensuring consistent and fair resolution of claims and reasonably convenient access to dispute resolution for individuals. SEC. 164. AMENDMENTS TO CRIMINAL LAW. Title 18, United States Code, amended with the addition of CHAPTER 90--PROTECTED HEALTH INFORMATION. Title 18, United States Code, amended with the addition of CHAPTER 90--PROTECTED HEALTH INFORMATION. This chapter includes definitions and regulations regarding obtaining, using, and disclosing protected health information under false pretenses for monetary gain. Sec. 1832 of CHAPTER 90 states that obtaining protected health information under false pretenses, such as requesting it from a health information trustee, can result in fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Sec. 1833 addresses the monetary gain from obtaining protected health information under false pretenses with the intent to sell or transfer it. Sec. 1834 of CHAPTER 90 prohibits the knowing and unlawful obtaining of protected health information from a health information trustee, with fines or imprisonment of up to 5 years. It also addresses the selling, transferring, or using of such information for profit or monetary gain, punishable by fines or imprisonment of up to 10 years. Sec. 1835 addresses the monetary gain from knowingly and unlawfully obtaining protected health information, with penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment. Sec. 1836 pertains to the knowing and unlawful use or disclosure of such information. Sec. 1837 deals with the monetary gain from knowingly selling, transferring, or using protected health information in violation of the Fair Health Information Practices Act of 1994, with penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment. Title II of the document includes amendments to Title 5, United States Code, specifically adding a new subsection to Section 552a regarding protected health information. The head of an agency that is a health information trustee shall promulgate rules to exempt a system of records containing protected health information from certain provisions, and a repeal is made to Section 552a(f)(3) of Title 5, United States Code. TITLE III--REGULATIONS; EFFECTIVE DATES; APPLICABILITY; AND RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS

The Secretary must establish regulations by July 1, 1996, to implement this Act. The Act and its amendments will be effective on January 1, 1997, with provisions imposing duties on the Secretary taking immediate effect upon enactment. Protected Health Information under this Act applies to information in a State from January 1, 1997, regardless of prior existence. Special purpose trustees are exempt, except for information received after January 1, 1997. Authorizations for disclosure before January 1, 1997, remain valid until July 1, 1998, or a specified date/event. Authorizations for disclosure before January 1, 1997, remain valid until July 1, 1998, or the specified date/event. SEC. 304. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER LAWS. This Act prevents the establishment, continuation, or enforcement of State laws that conflict with it, but does not intend to override State laws entirely. It also does not affect State or Federal laws regarding witness privileges in court. The Act does not override State laws on vital statistics reporting, abuse or neglect reporting, or notifications of emergency response employees about infectious diseases. HR 4077 IH--2 to HR 4077 IH--5 are sections of a bill that do not override State laws on vital statistics reporting, abuse or neglect reporting, or notifications of emergency response employees about infectious diseases.
